metadata.notes: Pattern based on administrative ration texts; "i" = oil, "ukim" = to measure out/ration; "X" likely a numeral placeholder.
Matches example 104 exactly: "kicib urnigar" = "under seal of Ur-nigar". Common Ur III administrative phrase indicating a sealed document or transaction by the named individual, Ur-nigār.

kin = surface/area (common in field measurements); bi = its (possessive); NUMB sar = quantified surface area in sar (standard Mesopotamian unit ~36m²). Matches patterns in examples like "NUMB sar GAN gecimmar" (Ex. 192), "NUMB sar al NUMB sarta" (Ex. 627).
Pattern-matched to administrative terminology: 'u' = "and"; 'sagnigura' = "debit account" or "credit entry" (cf. 'sagnigurakam' = "it is the debit"; 'nigkak' contexts). Literal: "and debit account".

predictions.reference: year : “ The silver-chair of Enlil was fashioned . ”
predictions.prediction: year : “ The kù-guza of Enlil was fashioned ; ”

metadata.translation: year : “ The kù-guza of Enlil was fashioned ; ”
metadata.notes: Follows standard Ur III year formula "mu [event]". Parallels example 427 "mu guza enlila badim" = "year : “ The throne of Enlil was fashioned ; ”". Here "ku guza" likely specifies a type of precious (kù = pure/silver/gold) throne or stool (guza) of Enlil, fashioned (badim).

predictions.reference: booked out of ( the account of ) Ahuni ,

metadata.notes: Pattern matches examples like "ki abasagata" = "from Abbasaga" (Ex. 39), "ki amarcubata" = "from Amar-šuba" (Ex. 26), "ki naramilita" = "from Naram-ilī" (Ex. 10), and many others where "ki PN1 PN2" indicates origin or account "from PN1, PN2". Aḫuni and Bazi are attested personal names in Ur III texts.

predictions.prediction: and the serpent of the sky

metadata.translation: and the serpent of the sky
metadata.notes: Possible reference to a celestial or mythological serpent, akin to "muc nanna" (serpent of Nanna) in example 150; "mucbian" may parse as muc-bi-an ("its serpent - sky"). Common in Sumerian curses or blessings.

Pattern matches examples like "ki buduta" → "from Budu", where "ki" indicates source/origin ("from") and "budu" is a personal name (cf. Example 604: budu unu → Budu, cowherd; common in Ur III administrative contexts for names following "ki"). "Ta" is a locative/directional ending.

predictions.reference: total : NUMB aš-c- ( workers ) , ‘field’ corporate slaves , foremen ;
predictions.prediction: total : NUMB field , male laborers , foreman

metadata.translation: total : NUMB field , male laborers , foreman
metadata.notes: Pattern-matched to administrative texts: "cunigin" = total; "NUMB GAN" = NUMB field(s)/surface area; "guruc" = male laborer(s); "ugula" = foreman. Cf. examples like 106 "cunigin NUMB geme u NUMB", 456 "NUMB gur ugula carakam", 656 "NUMB guruc ugula lugalmagure".

predictions.reference: NUMB millstone of high-quality black basalt ( ? )
predictions.prediction: NUMB (gur) fine emmer-flour from the Old-mill

metadata.translation: NUMB (gur) fine emmer-flour from the Old-mill
metadata.notes: Follows patterns in examples like "ekikken sumunta" (From Old-mill), "NUMB ziz" (NUMB emmer), and "NUMB zi sig" (NUMB fine flour). "Kikken" = old-mill (ekik); "adabar" = emmer-flour (zíz); "saga" = fine/good quality. Typical Ur III ration/administrative phrasing.
